questions.question_text: What would be two boundaries, defined in Scrum, that give guidance for teams to effectively self-organize? (Choose two.)

choices.C: Creating an integrated and potentially shippable Increment by the end of each Sprint.
choices.D: Having a mixture of different levels of skills and experience to promote domain knowledge sharing.
choices.B: Clearly defined functional teams within the Development Team to define handoff phases during development.
choices.A: Timeboxing the events in Scrum to allow for regular inspection and adaptation creating opportunities to adjust course in any given path.

questions.answer_description: Time-boxing promotes regularity and focus for self-organized teams. Having shippable Increments allows teams to collaboratively make decisions on what needs to be done next.

choices.B: Having consistent Sprint length across all Scrum Teams.
choices.A: How often team membership changes and the size of the Development Team.
choices.C: The level of expertise over the technology to be used, ability to release an Increment to the end users, and the risk of being disconnected from the stakeholders.

questions.question_text: What factors are best considered when defining the Sprint length?
Multiple Scrum Teams working from the same Product Backlog must have the same Sprint start dates.
questions.answer_description: Multiple Scrum Teams could have the same Sprint start dates but it is not mandatory as the importance is on being able to integrate their shippable Increments at the end of their Sprints.

choices.B: Daily Standup, Sprint Review, and Sprint Retrospective
choices.A: Daily Scrum, Sprint Review, and Sprint Retrospective
choices.C: Release Planning, Daily Scrum, and Sprint Review
choices.D: Grooming, Daily Status, and Sprint Review

questions.question_text: Which of the following are feedback loops in Scrum?

choices.B: When the requirements for the work to be done become unclear or not understood.
choices.D: When the Sprint Backlog is determined to be unachievable.
choices.A: When the availability of the Product Owner is less than expected.
choices.C: It can't. Only Product Owners can cancel Sprints.
